Description: Rim sherd of South Ionian pottery little-master cup with handle root; interior: dilute lines between black bands; top of rim glazed; exterior: myrtle leaf frieze with row of added white dots on stem; black band below at top of reserved handle zone.
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Antikenmuseum, Heidelberg. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd as belonging to a Type 9B South Ionian cup with everted rim and an Ionian Little Master Cup. Type 9B cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type XI (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-6). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type is the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 108-9, NAU 64, pl. 14 a)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.773) (Phase 3)
